title-group.article-title: The Dynamics of Cumulative Trauma and Trauma Types in Adults Patients With Psychiatric Disorders
title-group.subtitle: Two Cross-Cultural Studies

article-meta.aff: 1Center for Cumulative Trauma Studies, Stone Mountain, GA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Ibrahim A. Kira, PhD, Center for Cumulative Trauma Studies, 4906 Woodhurst Way, Decatur, GA, 30088, USA. Email: kiraaref@aol.com

abstract.p: There is an intricate divide between three major valid paradigms in studying traumatic processes: The psychiatric paradigm that focused mostly on the survival types of traumas and on posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), the psychoanalytic and developmental theories that focused on the effects of abandonment, maltreatment and betrayal, and the intergroup paradigm that focused on discrimination, genocide, and torture. The goal was to test the validity and utility of a framework that integrated the three trauma paradigms on mental health clients (MHC). Two studies were conducted in the USA and Egypt. In the first study 399 MHC were tested using cumulative trauma scale that utilizes the new framework and measures of mental health variables. The second study tested 432 MHC in a university psychiatric clinic in Egypt, utilizing comparable measures. The trauma profiles were examined and matched to the symptom profiles, psychiatric comorbidities, and global level of functioning. Egyptian participants reported relatively higher level of poverty, personal identity traumas (i.e., sexual abuse), and role identity traumas, while participants in the U.S. sample, that included refugees in addition to Americans, have more traumas of oppression, discrimination, torture, uprootedness, and abandonment. While cumulative trauma was associated with physical and mental health symptoms and comorbidities in both studies, different trauma profile of each predicted different configurations of symptoms. Current studies provided evidence of the validity and utility of the integrated new traumatology model, and its potential contribution to driving trauma field forward.

body.p: There is an intricate divide between three major paradigms in studying traumatic processes: the psychiatric paradigm that focused mostly on the survival types of traumatic stress and on posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) model (e.g., van der Kolk, Weisaeth, & van der Hart,1996), the psychoanalytic, and developmental paradigms that focused more on studying the effects of abandonment, child maltreatment, and other betrayal traumas in early childhood (e.g., Bowlby, 1988; Cassidy, & Shaver, 1999; Freyd, DePrince, & Gleaves, 2007), and the intergroup paradigm as evidenced in studying discrimination, genocide, torture, and other shared politically motivated micro and macro aggressions (e.g., for theoretical analysis of discrimination as a trauma, see Helms, Nicolas, & Green, 2010). Until recently, the three paradigms and their perspective theories and research, while some times overlap; have developed along relatively independent lines. In the first paradigm, trauma is defined as an event that involves actual or threatened death or serious injury or a threat to the physical integrity of self or others (American Psychiatric Association, 2004), and has potential of leading to PTSD symptoms.

In the second and third paradigms, trauma is mostly a process that can be triggered by internal or external events that threaten the person’s physical, personal, or social identities and this/her basic autonomy or dependence needs and have potential of yielding different symptoms that may include PTSD, and other syndromes(and not only PTSD). American Psychological Association APA trauma group’s (currently APA division 56) definition of trauma as “A process that leads to the disorganization of a core sense of self and world and leaves an indelible mark on one’s world views that psychological disorders often follow upon exposure to” represents this approach.

In the second paradigm traumatization process is mostly triggered by the caregiver failing to satisfy her/his natural responsibility to the dependency needs of the child, yielding feelings of insecurity and betrayal. Attachment disruptions and child maltreatment, in general, drives the child’s pathology in different areas of infant, adolescent, and adult life (e.g., Cassidy & Shaver, 1999). An important aspect of attachment theory is its assertion that healthy dependence on a reliably sensitive and responsive attachment figure is important for optimal functioning, well-being, and child subsequent development toward autonomy and interdependence (e.g., Bowlby, 1988). Evidence for this process has been shown particularly with regard to mother–child relationships (Cassidy, & Shaver, 1999; Kobak, Little, Race, & Acosta, 2001). However, attachment disruptions can continue and accumulate during early childhood and adolescence through, father abandonment, foster care placements, frequent changes in caregivers, causing cumulative attachment traumas, (Kira, 2001), and developmental disorders (van der Kolk, 2005), and suppress child IQ (Kira, Somers, Lewandowski, & Chiodo, 2012).

Child maltreatment, other than attachment disruptions, is one of the most stressful experiences that affect the development of children (Cicchetti & Lynch, 1995). Betrayal trauma theory (for a review, see Freyd et al., 2007) suggests that when a victim is dependent on the person that caused the harm, feeling of betrayal is implicated as one possible mechanism by which individuals may maintain distress and develop subsequent symptoms (Freyd et al., 2007). The literature on child maltreatment reveals its significant associations with different psychiatric symptoms and diagnoses, including depression, anxiety, conduct disorder, PTSD, personality disorders, substance abuse, suicidal and self-injurious behavior, somatization, and dissociation (e.g., Cicchetti & Lynch, 1995; De Bellis, 2001; Kessler, Davis, & Kendler, 1997; Macfie, Cicchetti, & Toth, 2001; see Baer, & Martinez, 2006 for a review).

In the third trauma paradigm the traumatization process is triggered by systemic social structural violence and interpersonal and intergroup macro and micro aggressions. Macro aggressions, for example targeted hate crimes, extreme poverty, cast system, and slavery (present, past or even those historical or cross-generationally transmitted), reverberate through secondary and tertiary interdependence and traumatization dynamics to those who belong to the same targeted group. While micro aggressions (e.g., Sue, 2010), demean, or exclude the targeted persons, they act as reminders of the macro aggressions and their threats, triggering feeling of annihilation anxiety, societal betrayal, stereotype threats, decreased self-esteem, and self-efficacy, and trigger the process of retraumatization.

The links between perceived ethnic discrimination and poor physical and mental health are fairly well-established (for meta-analysis see Pascoe & Richman, 2009). Prospective studies show that perceived ethnic discrimination precedes poor psychological and physical health, rather than the other way around (Brody et al., 2008; Gee & Waslemann, 2009). Similar results were found for discrimination of sexual minorities (e.g., Gilman et al., 2001); Asian Americans (e.g., Gee, Spencer, Chen, & Takeuchi, 2007), Mexican Americans (e.g., Flores, Tschann, Dimas, Pasch, & de Groat, 2010), immigrants (e.g., Berg et al., 2011), and refugees (e.g., Kira, Smith, Lewandowski, &Templin 2010a). Gender discrimination, was found to have negative mental health effects on females (e.g., Kira, Ashby, Lewandowski, Smith, & Odenat, 2012d; Kira et al., 2010a).

To summarize, each of the three paradigms while developed along different lines, sometimes overlapping, found severe physical and mental health consequences for the trauma types that were of their focus. An important clinical consideration is that in clinical practice and research, focusing on a single trauma type (for example, hurricane) can be misleading, and is only legitimate, when the client has experienced only this trauma type in his life time, which may be a rare situation. Polyvictimization that involves one trauma type (e.g., child abuse), does not preclude the concurrent polyvctimization with another trauma type (e.g., Hamby, Finkelhor, Turner, & Ormrod, 2010).

A new bi-dimensional developmentally based trauma framework (DBTF) integrated these three main streams in a unified development-based traumatology perspective that promised to advance the understanding of the etiology of mental health symptoms (e.g., Kira, 2001, 2004; Kira et al., 2006; Kira et al., 2008a, Kira et al., 2010a, 2010b). The new DBTF that is empirically supported provided wider and defined boundaries of what are traumatic stressors and their cumulative dynamics. The first dimension of DBTF is horizontal and development-based and is mostly focused on human-made traumas and includes attachment traumas (e.g., abandonment by parents of a child), identity traumas are a violation of individuation process emerged in adolescence and adulthood, that has at least three or four subkinds: Personal identity trauma, (e.g., violation of self-autonomy by sexual abuse, incest and other betrayal traumas), collective identity trauma, (e.g., targeted genocide, holocaust, slavery, and discrimination), and role identity or self-actualization trauma, (e.g., significant loss of life-savings, serious business failure, get unexpectedly fired, failed or dropped out of school or college), and physical identity (physical survival). The source of physical trauma can be either internal, for example sever pain and life threatening illnesses, or external, for example, life threatening accident, or nature-made, for example major natural disaster. In addition, interdependence dynamics that are one of the landmarks of adolescent and adult development may yield socially made trauma. Socially made traumas include secondary (e.g., witnessing violence or media relevant violence exposure, compassion fatigue of therapist) and tertiary such as cross-generationally transmitted trauma, (e.g., historical trauma, cast systems and poverty or extreme inequality). Some traumas reverberate horizontally and vertically in the fabric of social network to produce waves of secondary and tertiary traumas and can continue cross-generationally. Most traumas yield different levels of feelings of insecurity, violation by others and or betrayal (betrayal in close relationship, and systemic structural betrayal by larger society or dominant groups) or self-betrayal (e.g., Freyd, 1996).

The second dimension in DBTF is more vertical in terms of changing degree or level of severity and chronicity, and is based on the objective characteristics of traumatic events. Traumatic events may include, at this level, at least two kinds: Single episode trauma (Type I; e.g., car accident) and complex traumas. Complex traumas, in terms of chronicity, include two kinds: Type II (repeated similar traumatic episodes that ceased, for example sexual abuse; see Terr, 1991), and Type III (continuous, repeated and ongoing, e.g. racism). Such socially made traumas are mostly inter-group and social structure-based traumas and include such conditions as extreme poverty, cast system, slavery, and backlash against minorities. The socially made traumas can be transmitted through secondary and tertiary traumatization dynamics (Figley, 1995). The transmission course of socially made and other trauma types can either go in one step transmission, for example when it is transmitted from parent to child or vice versa, or in a multiple step transmission course. Multiple steps or cross-generation transmission of trauma (or tertiary trauma and beyond) can go either through family or through a collective experience (e.g., historical traumas, such as in the holocaust, and sociostructural traumas, such as in extreme poverty and relative deprivation; Cassiman, 2005; Kira, 2001, 2004; Kira et al., 2008a). Example of continuous collective identity traumas is protracted conflict. Examples of continuous chronic personal identity traumas are prostitution and trafficking. Type IV, in this taxonomy, is cumulative trauma (CT) across life time that have different cumulative dynamics. Tables 1 and 2 illustrate some of the elements of this model, (for more clarifications see tables and diagrams published in Kira, 2001; Kira et al., 2008a; Kira, Lewandowski, Somers, Yoon, & Chiodo, 2012a).

caption.p: Illustration of the Horizontal and Vertical Dimensions of the DTBF.

tr.td: e.g., Domestic violence for child, therapist exposure (Vicarious trauma)
Systemic Structure violence e.g., Extreme Poverty- Cast system
Unilateral and multilateral continuous traumatic stressors-Cumulative traumatic and nontraumatic stress across life span

tr.td: e.g., one step Transmission of attachment styles
Personal identity traumas e.g., rape, sexual abuse
Fear of self- or autonomy loss; betrayal by others
Collective identity (shared) traumas e.g., racism, slavery
Fear of group annihilation, subjugation; betrayal by society

Fear of loss of self-achievements, Self-betrayal,

fn.label: a
fn.p: e.g., identification, belonging, empathy, networking. PTSD = Posttraumatic stress disorder; CTD = Cumulative Trauma Related Disorder Measure.

body.p: The trans-theoretical DBTF framework allows measuring the effects of different trauma types including CT across life span. DBTF generated novel hypotheses, suggested new lines of research, attracted several new researchers and is promising to move us toward the “big picture” by integrating traumas across theories (e.g., Kira, 2001; Kira et al., 2008a, 2008b, 2011a, 2012a Kira, Lewandowski, Yoon, Somers, & Chiodo, 2012b; Martin, Cromer, DePrince, & Freyd, 2011).

Cumulative trauma (the effects of all the trauma types the person endured across life time) as well as polyvictimizations (the effects of concurrent or subsequent traumatization from the same trauma types) found to contribute significant unique variance in mental health beyond that accounted for by the combination of all aggregate trauma and victimization types (e.g., Cloitre et al, 2009; Finkelhor, Turner, & Hamby, 2005; Kira et al, 2008; Richmond, Elliott, Pierce, Aspelmeier, & Alexander, 2009). The stress sensitization hypothesis suggests that repeated trauma exposure increases the likelihood of a pathological response (e.g., Peretz, Baider, Ever-Hadani, & De-Nour, 1994). However, dose response model alone proved to be insufficient in explaining the risk for PTSD (e.g., Kaysan, Rosen, Bowman, & Resick, 2010).

CT model involves different dynamics that are not present in the single trauma model of PTSD, or in the complex trauma and complex PTSD model (e.g., Courtois & Ford, 2009; Herman, 1992). The accumulation and kindling dynamics can be present in CT. While Type I trauma (e.g., car accident) can yield PTSD, Type II trauma (e.g., sexual abuse) can yield complex PTSD, Type III traumas (e.g., discrimination and slavery) and the additive effects of combined different concurrent types of traumas can produce more severe symptoms of dissociation, hearing voices, suicidality and mental health comorbid syndromes (e.g., Kira, 2010; Shevlin, Houston, Dorahy, & Adamson, 2008). The dynamics of cumulative trauma is especially relevant for mental health patients and other cumulatively traumatized.

An important conceptual innovation in DBTF framework is the trauma profile analysis. Trauma profile describes the loads of different trauma types that endured by the individual, the group, or the culture. Trauma profile is usually presented in a contour or curve that outline the distribution of occurrence and intensity of each trauma types in the population. Trauma profile helps identify the core trauma/s for the individual or the group. Different trauma profiles entail different dynamics and outcomes and may require different interventions. The core trauma or dominant trauma types within the profile yield different symptoms (Kira, 2010; Kira et al., 2008). Trauma profiles of victims of political oppression, victims of sexual abuse and victims of abandonment are mostly different. Trauma profile differential analysis is important tool for good clinical assessment of the patient.

CT involves, at least, three kinds of traumas: core, peripheral, and triggering traumas. Core traumas sensitize and bias responses to potential retraumatizing and or triggering events. Triggering trauma is the trauma that actually set off the postcumulative trauma response (the last straw that breaks the camel’s back). Such single trauma can be the triggering event, rather than the core trauma, in such cumulative dynamics. Peripheral traumas are other traumas that are less salient in the person’s over all life traumatic experiences. However, peripheral traumas can move to be salient if has been reactivated by similar traumatic events. This is important in clinical science, as we may be focusing on the triggering and not the core trauma/s, and ignoring the operating dynamics.

Previous studies of the etiology of mental disorders, in mental health patients, identified traumatic stress as major contributor to such disorders (e.g., Rutter, 2000). Research, used the psychiatric paradigm showed that trauma victimizations (51%-98%) are highly prevalent among persons with severe mental illness (schizophrenia, bipolar disorder) who were served within public-sector clinics (e.g., Ford & Fournier, 2007; Mueser et al., 1998). Most previous research used one paradigm, or the other that was less comprehensive to identify traumatization level. It is important to study the etiology of mental disorders from the integrated DBTF traumatology that consider all trauma types the individual endured.

To test the validity and utility of the DBTF, we plan to study mental health patients (MHP). One of the core traumas unique for MHP is internalized stigma of mental illness (ISMI). ISMI includes micro and macro aggressions perpetrated by the public, and internalized or resisted by MHP. ISMI has serious effects on their self-esteem, self-efficacy beliefs and mental health (e.g., Corrigan, Watson, & Barr, 2006).

sec.title: The Goals of the Research
sec.p: The goal of this research is test the validity and utility of DBTF that integrated the three trauma paradigms, to evaluate the contribution of different trauma types and CT dynamics to clients’ physical and mental health and functioning. Another aim is to explore if these dynamics recur across two communities which each have different trauma profile. We will compare between outpatient MHP clients in Zaqazek University clinic, Egypt and those in another clinic in Dearborn Michigan (USA).

sec.title: The First Study: Dearborn, Michigan, USA Sample
Procedures
sec.p: Participants were 95% of all active mental health clients that came for a psychiatrist, therapist, or case manager visit during the 6 months from August 2004 to February 2005 in a MH clinic in Dearborn Michigan, United States (95% consented to participate). Participants were interviewed face to face by licensed bilingual therapists or certified experienced bilingual clinical case managers for the duration of 45 to 60 min. The data was collected as part of a mental health antistigma outcome project which was authorized by federal authorities and approved by the IRB and research committees of the authors’ institution. Informed consents were obtained from participants. No identifying information, linking subject to the data, was recorded and the disclosure of the data could not reasonably place the subjects at any risk. Participants were 399 mental health clients and included 82.7% persons of Arabic immigrants or refugees. The balance included Americans as well as refugees and Asylum seekers from other countries. Table 3 provides their demographics along with the demographics of participants of the second study.

caption.p: Demographic Characteristics of the Two Samples.

sec.title: Measures, Demographics and Clinical Data
sec.p: The measures used in this study as identified in the following section have previously been shown to have adequate reliability and validity on Iraqi and Arab populations and in Arabic and English languages (Kira, Clifford, Wiencek, & Al-haidar, 2001; Kira et al., 2006, 2008a). These measures were previously constructed in English and subsequently translated into Arabic by three bilingual mental health professionals who each individually translated the measures and then met together to establish a consensus on the final version. A fourth mental health professional did the reverse translation. These measures were pilot tested in focus groups. We provided Arabic and English versions to our research subjects. In addition to these measures we collected demographic and clinic data from the clients files considering diagnoses, global assessment of functioning (GAF) as diagnosed by clinic psychiatrists. Further we developed, from this data, a mental health comorbidity index, which is the number of primary and secondary diagnoses the patient had. Comorbidity is important measure of the severity of illnesses.

sec.title: Independent (Predictor) Variables Measures
sec.p: Cumulative Trauma Scale (CTS) includes 61 items and is based on the DBTF (Kira, 2001; Kira et al., 2008a, 2008b). Each item describes an extremely stressful event that belongs to 6 different types of traumas: Attachment, personal identity, collective identity, secondary, survival, and achievement traumas. Examples are as follows: I was led to sexual contact by one of my caregiver/parents, my mother has abandoned or left/or separated from me when I was a child. The participant is asked to report if he/she has experienced it or not, how many times he have experienced the event, the age of first one, and how much it affected him or her positively or negatively on a scale from 0 to 7 (positive and negative appraisal). The measure provides us with general scales for two of the cumulative trauma doses: Occurrence and frequency of happenings, two appraisal subscales: Negative and positive appraisal. It includes, at this level, four subscales for each trauma types. In the analysis, in this study, we used the occurrence of traumas of each type (e.g., personal identity traumas) as an index of polytraumatization of this trauma type, in addition to the cumulative occurrence of all trauma types (cumulative trauma or cumulative trauma load). This information allows for describing the trauma profile, in addition to conducting other advanced analyses. The measure has been used previously with different clinical and community populations of adults and children and proved to have adequate reliability (Alpha of .80-.90), good construct and predictive validity (Kira et al., 2008a, 2008b; Kira et al., 2011a). The reliability of the CTS was found adequate in the current study (alpha = .98).

Internalized Stigma of Mental Illness Inventory (ISMI) is a 29-item scale. Each statement is rated on the following 4-point anchored Likert-type scale: 1 = strongly disagree, 2 = disagree, 3 = agree, 4 = strongly agree. Items were grouped thematically “a priori” into five subscales: Alienation, Stereotype Endorsement, Perceived Discrimination, Social Withdrawal, and Stigma Resistance. The 29-item ISMI had good internal consistency (α = .90, N = 127). The test-retest reliability coefficient was r = .92 (p<.05, N=16; Ritsher, Otilingam, & Grajales, 2003). The measure and its subscales proved to have adequate internal consistency except for the SR subscale (Ritsher et al., 2003). The Arabic version of ISMI was found to have robust psychometrics (Kira, Lewandowski, Templin, Mohanesh, & Abdulkhalek, 2011b). It has good reliability in both versions in the current data for all groups. Alpha for the whole sample was .95. ISMI, for mental health patients can act as an independent and mediating variable.

sec.title: Dependent (Outcome) Variables Measures
sec.p: Annihilation Anxiety (AA) Scale is based on the assumption that there are at least three main sources of the emergence of annihilation threats: Threats to personal identity, to direct threats to collective identity such as discrimination, and indirect threats from severe societal structural inequalities. A three items that represents the three components were used, for example, because of what has happened to me personally or is happening to me personally, I sometimes worry that I just lose my sense of self (I worry that I will cease to exist as an individual person). The answer was structured on a 5 point-Likert-type scale: 5 = Strongly Agree, 4 = Agree, 3 = Not sure, 2 = Disagree, 1 = Strongly Disagree. The higher the sum of the three items provides the higher of feeling of AA. The scale had been used before on Iraqi refugees and on other three samples of Palestinians and found to have good reliability (alpha. ranged between. 90-95), convergent discriminant and predictive validity (Kira et al., 2012c). It has an alpha of .93 in the current study.

Anxiety Subscale of the Depression Anxiety Stress Scales-Anxiety DASS-A: (14 items): DASS is a 42-item scale developed by Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995, and includes three subscales that measure depression, anxiety, and stress. DASS-A subscale measures anxiety, which is increasingly used in different clinical and research settings. It has adequate convergent validity, with reliability of .84 in nonclinical and .91 in clinical samples (e.g., Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995). Its alpha reliability in the present study is .95.

Clinician-Administered PTSD Scale (CAPS-2; Blake et al., 1990) is widely used to assess PTSD. It is a structured clinical interview that assesses 17 symptoms rated on frequency and severity on a 5-point scale. CAPS demonstrated high reliability with a range from 0.92 to 0.99 and showed good convergent and discriminant validity. It has four factor subscales: re-experiencing, avoidance, arousal and emotional numbness, detachment or dissociation (Palmieri, Weathers, Difede & King, 2007). In this study, we used the frequency subscale of CAPS-2. It has high reliability with an alpha of 0.97 in current data.

Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Measure, CES-D (Radloff, 1977): is a 20-item scale. Each item is assessed on a 4-point scale and reflects the frequency that each symptom was experienced (0 = none of the time, 3 = all of the time). A cutoff score of ≥16 is commonly used for the CES-D to indicate a need for further assessment of the presence of major depressive disorder (Radloff, 1977). High internal consistency (ranging from .85 to .92) and good convergent and discriminant validity, sensitivity and specificity had been reported (e.g., Mulrow et al., 1995). It has alpha of .91 in the present study.

sec.title: Cumulative trauma related disorders measure (CTD)
sec.p: This 15-item measure has been developed on five community and clinic samples of adults, adolescent Arab, and African Americans. It is an index measure that covers 13 different symptoms: Depression, anxiety, somatization, dissociation, auditory and visual hallucinations, avoidance of being with people, paranoid ideations, concentration and memory deficits, loss of self-control, feeling suicidal, and feeling like hurting self. Exploratory and confirmatory factor analyses found four factors (four subscales): Executive function deficits, suicidality, dissociation/psychosis, and depression/anxiety comorbidity. It has good reliability (ranged from .85 to .98). Test-retest reliability in a 6-week interval was .76. The measure has good predictive validity. Different kinds of traumas and cumulative trauma accounted for significant variance as predictors of CTD symptoms (Kira, Clifford & Al-Haider, 2003; Kira, Templin, & Lewandowski, 2012). In the current data, its alpha was .91.

Physical Health: Physical Health was measured by a single question asking the client to rate his/her current general health on a scale from 1 to 4. (1 = very good health, 2 = good, 3 = poor, 4 = very poor).

sec.title: Analyses
sec.p: We analyzed the prevalence of trauma types and cumulative trauma load to identify the trauma profile in each sample. We calculated the prevalence of different mental health conditions in the sample to explore the severity of symptoms and levels of comorbidity. A series of simultaneous multiple regression analyses were conducted with cumulative trauma CT, different trauma types (personal identity, collective identity, attachment, survival, secondary and ISMI traumas) as independent variables, and depression, anxiety, annihilation anxiety, PTSD, CTD, mental health comorbidities, and global assessment of functioning (all are continuous variables), as dependent variables. We controlled for age, gender, cultural group, marital status, income, education, period of stay in the United States, and religion, as covariates to disentangle the significant effects of each. For all regression analyses that we conducted in the two studies, we tested for multicolinearity. VIF (variance inflation factor) for all predictor variables ranged between 1.00 and 1.50, which indicated low colinearity (the recommended cut off score for multicolinearity is 5.00, e.g., O’Brien, 2007). Furthermore, we tested different plausible path models that reflected assumptions about the effects of CT and trauma types that have higher incidence rate, on mental health conditions, using structural equation modeling (SEM) with AMOS 7.0 (Arbuckle, 2006). We used bootstrap (N = 200 samples) with bias-corrected confidence intervals to test the significance of the direct and indirect effects. Bootstrapping is more robust modern statistics that are used to generate a sampling distribution that is utilized to compute p values, and generate confidence intervals for the direct and indirect effects (e.g., Erceg-Hurn & Mirosevich, 2008).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Descriptive Results Trauma Profile: Table 4 describes the trauma profile characteristics of each sample. Mental Health Profile: For mental health symptoms, 82% scored 16 or higher on the CES-D scale (16 is the cutoff point for clinical depression recommended for this scale); 83.8% scored in the elevated range of PTSD symptoms (scoring 26 or above in PTSD frequent symptoms). For DASS-A (anxiety) 74% scored 10 or higher (10 is the recommended cutoff score for moderate to severe anxiety on this scale). For CTD items, over 38% reported that sometimes they hear voices and/or see things others do not hear or see; 17.1% felt very much or thought about killing themselves (suicidality). Mean GAF score was 48.85 with standard deviation (SD) of 4.18. For diagnoses by clinic psychiatrists, 45.4% have major depressive disorder, 42.3% have PTSD, 7.7% have anxiety disorder, 20.3% have psychotic disorder, 1.5% have bipolar disorder; and 8% have OCD as primary diagnoses. For comorbidity, 37% have at least one secondary diagnosis on Axis I, and 74% have at least one diagnosis on Axis III (diagnosed medical condition).

caption.p: The Percentages of Trauma Types Endured by Each Sample.

tr.td: All endured at least one type of trauma (mean of 10.34 and standard deviation of 7.70., only 4 suffered from a single trauma type, 11% suffered from at least 3 traumas, while 80% suffered from 4 or more traumas

30.6% expressed some positive appraisal; while 85% reported negative appraisals.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Positive appraisal was associated with positive self-esteem and futuristic orientation.

sec.title: Multiple Regression Analyses Results
sec.p: CT predicted significant increase in depression, annihilation anxiety, general anxiety, PTSD, CTD, comorbidity, and reduced global functioning. Collective identity traumas, in this sample, were the highest trauma type that predicted all mental health (MH) conditions, especially of annihilation anxiety (β = .95***, R2 = .88), followed by personal identity traumas that predicted to a lesser degree all MH variables, however, their prediction of decreased GAF was the highest among all trauma types (β = −.47***, R2 = .37). Attachment traumas predicted depression, and to some degree CTD, however, their prediction of decreased GAF scores was the second highest among all trauma types (β = −.420***, R2 = .39). Secondary traumas predicted all MH variables with different degrees of intensity. Survival traumas predicted all MH variables except MH comorbidity and GAF. Internalized stigma of mental illness predicted all MH variables and was the highest predictor of CTD and PTSD. Collective identity and secondary traumas were the strongest predictors of mental health comorbidity. Table 5 summarizes the results.

caption.p: Multiple Regressions for The effects of Cumulative Trauma, Trauma Types on Mental and Physical Health Variables after Controlling for Demographics and for Other Relevant Variables in the USA and Egyptian Samples.

fn.p: Note: GAF = global assessment of functioning; AA = annihilation anxiety; MHC = mental health comorbidities; PHC = physical health comorbidity; GD = gender discrimination; PTSD = posttruamatic stress disorder; CTD = Cumulative Trauma Related Disorder Measure; XX= variables were not measured.

sec.title: Path Models
sec.p: Type III traumas, for example, political oppression, discrimination, and to some degree poverty, are higher than other trauma types in the trauma profile of the American sample. We tested different plausible path models that represented this profile. The model included poverty, torture, political oppression and discrimination, as predictors, ISMI as mediator, and PTSD, depression, anxiety, CTD and physical health as dependent variables. The model had good fit with the data (Chi Square = 32.473, df = 19, p = .028. CFI = .991, RMSEA = .042). Poverty had direct significant positive effects (increased severity of their symptoms) on PTSD, ISMI, CTD and poor health. Further, it had indirect significant positive effects on PTSD, CTD, depression, anxiety, and poor health. Stereotyping and Racial Profiling had direct significant positive effects on PTSD and indirect positive significant effects on CTD, depression, anxiety, and poor health. Social and Political Oppression had positive direct significant effects on ISMI and depression and indirect significant positive effects on increased PTSD, CTD, depression, anxiety and poor health. Torture had direct significant positive effects on PTSD and indirect significant positive effects on CTD, depression, anxiety, and poor health. Internalized Stigma of Mental Illness (ISMI) had direct significant positive effects on PTSD and CTD and indirect significant positive effects on depression, anxiety, and poor health. ISMI partially mediated the effects of poverty and political oppression on PTSD, CTD, and anxiety (see Table 6).

caption.p: Decomposition of Standardized Direct, Indirect, Total Effects of Poverty, Political Oppression, Racial Profiling, and Torture and Their Confidence Intervals on Health and Mental Health (Michigan Clinic).

sec.title: The Second Study: Zagazik University MH Clinic, Egypt (Egyptian Study)
sec.p: Procedures: Data were collected from patients who attended the Zagazik University out-patients mental health clinic, Egypt. They included all patients admitted from May 1, 2010 to April 30, 2011. Interviews were conducted face to face by clinic professionals as part of a routine assessment. Confidentiality and anonymity were strictly enforced. Research protocol was approved by the university’s IRB. Furthermore, a detailed information of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (4th ed.) five axes diagnoses for each client were carefully assessed by university psychiatry professors and residents as part of routine clinic assessment. The information was collected from clients’ records and included primary and secondary diagnosis in Axis I and Axis II, as well the physical illnesses on Axis III, and the range of problems on Axis IV and the general level of functioning score on Axis V (GAF). We used this wealth of diagnostic data, collected from clients’ records, to develop indices of mental and physical health comorbidity. Mental health comorbidity index is the number of primary and secondary diagnoses the clients had on the Axis I and II. Physical health comorbidity index is the number of health diagnoses the client had on Axis III.
Participants were 432 mental health clients. Table 3 includes their demographic characteristics.

Measures In addition to CES-D, PTSD, DASS, and ISMI, which have been used in the first study, we added Rosenberg measure of self-esteem and a short measure for futuristic orientation. We used the short version of cumulative trauma CTS that has added subscale of gender discrimination (Kira et al., 2008a), instead of the long version used in the previous study (the short form correlation with long version was R = .82***).

sec.title: Cumulative Trauma Scale CTS-S (short form)
sec.p: The CTS-S is a 32-item instrument that measures cumulative trauma in terms of frequency, types, and impact as indicated in the long versionFactor analysis found six types of trauma: Collective identity trauma, family trauma, secondary trauma, personal identity trauma, survival trauma, and attachment trauma. The instrument followed the same instructions used in the long version discussed earlier. This instrument has shown adequate internal consistency (a = .85) for adults. The instrument has shown predictive validity as cumulative trauma was significantly correlated with PTSD (r = .54,p < .001), cumulative trauma related disorders (r = .24, p < .001), and poor health (r = .37, p < .001). The instrument also showed divergent validity as it was significantly negatively correlated with sociocultural adjustment (r = −.25, p < .001), and futuristic orientation (r = −.37, p < .001; Kira et al., 2008a). It has adequate reliability in the current data (alpha = .83).

The Rosenberg self-esteem scale (RSES), was developed by Dr. Morris Rosenberg (1965). It is a 10-item scale with items answered on a 4-point Likert-type scale—from strongly agree to strongly disagree and scored from 0 to 3. Five of the scale items have positively worded statements and five have negatively worded ones. The scale measures global self-esteem. The RSES has been translated and adapted to various languages including Arabic. Rosenberg reported good psychometrics for the scale and its reliability ranging from .85 to .88. The scale α was (.87) in the current sample.

sec.title: Futuristic optimistic orientation (FOO)
sec.p: This 2-item scale assesses the degree to which the individual look to the future optimistically and perceive adversity as an opportunity to grow. It was developed in previous studies of Iraqi refugees (Kira et al., 2003). It includes the following items: (a) I feel optimistic and enthusiastic about the future. (b) I have very clear goals and vision. The participant was asked if he agrees or disagrees on 5-point scale. Higher scores indicated higher futuristic orientation. It was found to have good reliability (alpha 0.72), construct, and concurrent and discriminant validity and found to have one factor structure. It was associated with sociocultural adjustment, posttraumatic growth, and was negatively correlated with CTD. It had alpha of .66 in the current data.

sec.title: Descriptive Results
sec.p: Trauma Profile: Table 4 includes the parameters of trauma profile of the sample.

Mental Health Profile: Hundred percent scored 16 or higher on the CES-D scale (16 is the cutoff point for clinical depression recommended for this scale); 90% scored in the elevated range of the presence of PTSD symptoms. For DASS-A (anxiety) 67.2% scored 10 or higher (10 is the recommended cutoff score for moderate to severe anxiety on this scale). For comorbidity, 35% had 3 to 4 diagnoses; the mean comorbidity for the sample is 2.06, with SD of 1.043. 45.6% had at least one or physical health condition, with mean physical comorbidity of 1.16 and SD of 1.50. Psychiatrists diagnosed 26.4% to have schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders, 37.7% to have mood disorders, 18.8% to have anxiety disorders, and 17.1 to have other diagnosis as primary diagnosis. Mean GAF score was 52.48 with SD of 4.67.

Multiple Regression analyses results Multiple regression analyses were conducted with cumulative trauma, different trauma types (personal identity, collective identity, attachment, survival, secondary, gender discrimination, and ISMI traumas), as independent variables, and depression, anxiety, PTSD, mental health comorbidities, physical disorders comorbidity, and global assessment of functioning, as dependent variable, controlling for gender, marital status, age, education, residency (rural vs. city), SES (socioeconomic status), employment status and religion as covariates. Cumulative trauma predicted, as hypothesized, highly significant elevation in depression, anxiety, PTSD, mental health comorbidity, physical disorders comorbidity, and reduced GAF. In this sample ISMI was the highest predictor of mental health comorbidity (β = .73****, R2 = .57), and of reduced global level of functioning (β =.-.90****, R2 = .81), and was a strong predictor of all mental and physical health variables. Personal identity traumas, in this sample, were relatively the second highest trauma types predictor of all mental and physical health (MH) conditions, especially of physical disorders comorbidity (β = .40****, R2 = .20), and PTSD (β = .36****, R2 = .22), followed by collective identity traumas that predicted to a lesser degree all MH variables. Attachment traumas predicted PTSD. Secondary traumas predicted all MH variables with different degrees of intensity. Survival traumas predicted all MH variables except GAF. Gender discrimination predicted anxiety, PTSD, and physical disorders comorbidity (see Table 5).

Path analysis Results To check the effects of specific Type III traumas of poverty, as well as sexual abuse (Type II trauma) which are more present in the trauma profile of Egypt based sample, and the mediation hypothesis of ISMI, we tested different plausible path models. The model that had the best fit includes poverty, sexual abuse, life threatening accidents (a survival trauma), torture, and gender discrimination (Type III trauma for females) as independent variables, ISMI as a mediating variable, and PTSD, anxiety, depression, psychiatric comorbidity, health disorders comorbidity, GAF, as well as self-esteem and futuristic orientation as dependent variables. The model has excellent fit with the data (Chi Square = 47.727, df = 51, p = .604, CFI = 1.000, RMSEA = .000).

In the model, poverty had highly significant direct positive effects on ISMI, PTSD and depression, and negative effects on self-esteem. Poverty had highly significant indirect positive effects on PTSD, depression, anxiety, psychiatric disorders comorbidity (PDC), physical health disorders comorbidity (PHDC) and negative effects on self-esteem, futuristic orientation and GAF. Sexual abuse had significant direct positive effects on ISMI, PTSD, anxiety, and PHDC. It had significant indirect effects on PTSD, depression, anxiety, PDC, PHDC, and negative effects on self-esteem, futuristic orientation and GAF. ISMI had highly significant direct effects on PTSD, PDC, PHDC, and highly significant negative effects on in self-esteem, futuristic orientation, and global level of functioning. ISMI has significant indirect effects on anxiety. ISMI mediated the effects of poverty, sexual abuse, torture, and gender discrimination on PDC, PHDC, and negative effects on self-esteem, futuristic orientation and GAF. Life threatening accident had significant direct effects on PTSD and direct and indirect effects on depression. It had indirect effects on anxiety, PDC, PHDC, and negative effects on self-esteem, futuristic orientation and GAF. The indirect effects may be small but significant. Torture had direct effects on PTSD and anxiety, and indirect effects on depression and anxiety. It had small but significant negative effects on futuristic orientation. Gender discrimination had direct effects on PTSD and direct and indirect effects on PHDC. It had indirect small but significant effects on depression and anxiety and negative effects on self-esteem (see Table 7).

caption.p: Decomposition of Standardized Direct, Indirect, Total Effects and Their Confidence Intervals and Significance on Poverty, Torture, Life Threatening Accident, Gender Discrimination, Sexual Abuse, ISMI, on PTSD, Depression, Anxiety, Self-Esteem, Future Orientation, Mental Health Comorbidity, Physical Health Comorbidity, and Global Level of Functioning.

sec.title: Summary of Comparative Results
sec.p: Egyptians are mostly Muslims that live in a Muslim majority, while most of U.S. participants are Muslims, who live, as a minority, in a Christian majority. Most of them are refugees. For cumulative trauma load, both communities are multiply traumatized; however, their trauma profiles are different. U.S. participants had more trauma load, but their appraisal of trauma was relatively more positive. Poverty and ISMI were relatively a shared core collective identity trauma for samples; oppression, discrimination and up-rootedness were unique core collective identity traumas in the U.S. sample. The Egyptian participants reported relatively higher level of poverty (95% compared to 68% in the American Sample) and much less level of discrimination (2% compared to 38% in the U.S. sample). The participants in the U.S. sample have added trauma of oppression and much higher torture trauma (19% compared to 3% in the Egyptian sample), and being uprooted from their favorite environment (47% compared to 25% for the Egyptian sample).

Sexual abuse and role identity were core personal identity traumas, as well as secondary traumas, in the Egyptian sample. Egyptian participants reported higher level of sexual abuse (22% compared to less than 5% reported in the American sample). They reported higher levels of role identity (achievement traumas; 17%% compared to 8.3% for the American participants). They reported higher level of secondary traumas (76% compared to 44% for the American sample). Abandonment trauma seemed to be one of the core traumas in the American sample participants. They reported higher abandonment traumas (9.5% compared to 3.2% for the Egyptian sample).

The results of multiple regressions and path analyses reflected the salient consistent effects of CT and the differential effects of different trauma profiles. The effects of cumulative trauma in both samples were similar as it was associated with, significant increase in depression, anxiety, PTSD, mental and physical disorders comorbidities, and reduced global functioning. The effects of different traumas reflected similarities and differences according to the different representations of each trauma in the trauma profile for each. In the U.S. study where participants were exposed to more oppression, discrimination and torture, collective identity traumas were the strongest predictor of mental health variables followed by personal identity traumas. Oppression and discrimination (Type III traumas) have significant effects on increased PTSD, CTD, depression, anxiety, and poor health. In the Egyptian sample personal identity (e.g., sexual abuse), and attachment traumas were more prevalent. Personal identity traumas (sexual abuse) in the Egyptian sample was strong predictor of increased ISMI, PTSD, anxiety, depression, psychiatric disorders comorbidity, physical health disorders comorbidity and decreased self-esteem, futuristic orientation and GAF. However, ISMI and poverty were salient predictors of different mental health indicators in both samples. Poverty, and ISMI in both samples, had highly significant effects on increased, PTSD, anxiety, psychiatric disorders comorbidity, physical health disorders comorbidity and decreased self-esteem, futuristic orientation and GAF. Secondary and survival trauma occurrence were comparable in both samples. Secondary traumas predicted all MH variables with different degrees of intensity in both samples. Survival traumas predicted all MH variables except global level of functioning in both samples. Attachment traumas predicted depression, and to some degree CTD, and high decrease in global level of functioning in U.S. sample (participants have relatively higher attachment traumas). Attachment traumas, which were less in the Egyptian sample, predicted PTSD only in this sample.

sec.title: Discussion and Conclusions
sec.p: The trans-theoretical model we developed crossed over the intricate divide between the three traumatology paradigms. Results highlighted the DBTF model’s flexibility and sensitivity and provided preliminary evidence of the validity and utility of the integrated new model, and its potential contribution to driving trauma field forward. The results confirmed the relevance of trauma profile analysis in determining the health and mental health consequences of traumatic stress. Type III trauma (e.g., poverty, ISMI), in both samples have more serious effects than Type I (car accident), and Type II (e.g., sexual abuse).

The results replicated the three trauma paradigms findings of the negative effects of each trauma type. Previous studies found that ethnic and racial discrimination have serious mental and physical health effects (e.g., Brody et al., 2008; Gee & Waslemann, 2009; Pascoe & Richman, 2009). Gender discrimination was found to have negative mental health on females and relatively positive mental health effects for males (e.g., Kira et al., 2010b; Kira et al., 2012d). Abandonment, child maltreatment, and sexual abuse literatures provide convincing evidence of their negative effects (e.g., Baer, & Martinez, 2006; Cassidy, & Shaver, 1999; Cicchetti & Lynch, 1995; Kessler et al., 1997). The negative effects of survival traumas, for example, war and violence are well documented, especially their effects on veterans (e.g., van der Kolk et al., 1996). It is important to assess for all trauma variables represented in the three trauma paradigms and tailor treatment to the relevant core traumas for the individual person.

One of the especially neglected aspect of trauma assessment is the construction of cultural/gender identity, discrimination, poverty, and ethnicity. The effects of different identity traumas collective, personal and role identity on global level of functioning, comorbidity, different mental health variables, are highly negative in both samples. The effects of poverty, as well as ISMI in mental health patients, are especially extremely negative in both samples. Torture, gender discrimination, oppression, and stereotyping have direct significant effects on PTSD. The results of the effects of gender discrimination by society on PTSD, physical disorders comorbidity, depression, anxiety, and decreased self-esteem replicated previous studies that put gender discrimination, often ignored in assessment, on the trauma map (e.g., Kira et al., 2010, 2012d). Results indicated that it is increasingly important to address the origins of structural violence and intergroup traumas in affected individuals and groups.

The new integrated model has more promise to explore the cumulative dynamics in all trauma types without ignoring any. The new trans-theoretical paradigm would enrich and enhance the contributions of different theories in their related focused and applications, through comparative analysis, reconfiguration, and looking to the big picture.

DBTF and its applications have important implications for trauma assessment, clinical intervention, and research. The results highlighted the importance of assessing trauma profile and cumulative trauma dynamics, for each patient, using the integrative framework, and not only one type of trauma. Limited assessment that focuses on one trauma type, or a single trauma, can be misleading, prevent clear case conceptualization and impede effective treatment. When studying the effects of trauma or cumulative trauma that drives pathology, each trauma paradigm, used its trauma types to determine the outcomes, ignoring the other potential operating dynamics of the other trauma types. Each trauma type that was the main concern of each of the three trauma paradigms has significant role in the mental health symptom production. Focusing on only one type or ignoring any one of them would be a serious clinical mistake that can amount, at least in some cases, to clients’ neglect. The presenting problem can mask the core trauma/s and the cumulative dynamics. Some used the triggering trauma ignoring the cumulative dynamics that hide the core salient (index) trauma/s.

To conclude, there are at least four lessons that are derived from current research. First, the integrative model of trauma assessment that evaluate all trauma types using the DBTF integrative approach has more clinical utility, theoretical, and empirical validity. Second, the configuration of trauma profile that determine empirically which is the core more salient trauma/s the individual encountered is important clinical tool derived from the new DBTF paradigm. Third, relying on the assessment of single trauma type, ignoring the dynamics of polyvictimization within each trauma types and cumulative trauma that measure concurrent traumatization/victimization by different trauma types may be a wrong approach and can amount to clients neglect and or faulty spurious research approach. More studies are needed to identify the different or similar dynamics of different trauma types in different populations and cultures and to perfect the integrated measurement model to be more inclusive and parsimonious. Finally, the innovations of the current trauma framework may help in charting the terrain for optimal sound and updated guidelines for trauma and complex trauma treatment and service-delivery for the trauma victims.
